Package org.wmn4j.notation.elements

Class Pitch

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.wmn4j.notation.elements.Pitch
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<Pitch>
    public final class Pitch
extends Object
implements Comparable<Pitch>
    The Pitch class represents a pitch. Pitches consist of the basic pitch letter Pitch.Base, alter number which tells by how many half-steps the pitch is altered, and octave number which tells the octave of the note. Octave number is based on scientific pitch notation. This class is immutable.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class Description
      static class  Pitch.Base
      The letter in a pitch name.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field Description
      static int ALTER_LIMIT
      The limit for altering notes in half-steps (=3).
      static int MAX_OCTAVE
      Highest allowed octave number (=10).

    • Method Detail

      • getPitch

        public static Pitch getPitch​(Pitch.Base pitchName,
                             int alter,
                             int octave)
        Returns a Pitch object.
        Parameters:
        pitchName - the letter on which the name of the pitch is based.
        alter - by how many half-steps the pitch is altered up (positive values) or down (negative values).
        octave - the octave of the pitch.
        Returns:
        Pitch object with the specified attributes.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if alter is greater than ALTER_LIMIT of smaller than -1*ALTER_LIMIT, or if octave is negative or larger than MAX_OCTAVE.

      • toInt

        public int toInt()
        Get an integer representation of this Pitch. This is the MIDI number of the pitch (middle-C, C4, being 60). A Pitch is transformed into an integer using the formula pitchAsInteger = base + alter + (octave + 1) * 12 , where base is defined by the letter in the pitch name: C = 0, D = 2, E = 4, F = 5, G = 7, A = 9, B = 11. Alter is the number of sharps, or the number of flats * -1. For example, C#4 = 0 + 1 + 5 * 12 = 61 and Db4 = 2 - 1 + 5 * 12 = 61.
        Returns:
        this Pitch as an integer.

      • getPitchClass

        public PitchClass getPitchClass()
        Returns the PitchClass of this Pitch.
        Returns:
        the pitch class of this Pitch.

        public int getPCNumber()

      • equalsEnharmonically

        public boolean equalsEnharmonically​(Pitch other)
        Test enharmonic equality. Compare this to other for enharmonic equality.
        Parameters:
        other - Pitch against which this is compared.
        Returns:
        true if this is enharmonically equal to other, otherwise false.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        String representation of Pitch. Pitch objects are represented as strings of form bao, where b is the base letter in the pitch name, a is the alteration (sharps # or flats b), and o is the octave number. For example middle C-sharp is represented as the string C#4.
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        the string representation of this Pitch.

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(Object o)
        Compare this Pitch for equality with Object o. Two objects of class Pitch are equal if they have the same ' base letter, alterations (sharps or flats), and same octave. Pitches that are enharmonically the same but spelt differently are not equal. For example, C#4 != Db4.
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        o - Object against which this is compared for equality.
        Returns:
        true if Object o is of class Pitch and has the same, pitch base, alterations, and octave as this.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo​(Pitch other)
        Compare this pitch against other for pitch height.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<Pitch>
        Parameters:
        other - the Pitch against which this is compared.
        Returns:
        negative integer if this is lower than other, positive integer if this is higher than other, 0 if pitches are (enharmonically) of same height.
